pros: Decent entry level pay. 4 day work week.
cons:
variable length of day. could be 10 hours, could be 16 hours. The culture is that of disrespect and rudeness. Every selector has to look out for themself to attempt to hit rate. Theres incentives if you meet or exceed 100% rate, but it is almost impossible to meet in dry, the largest section of warehouse. If you don't meet 95% rate, you will be reprimanded until you're terminated. Turnover rate is incredibly high, and for good reason. Most people will be used up and tossed out like a worn out washcloth. If you can persevere, and are incredibly fit, you can succeed and make a living selecting at UNFI.
Advice to Management
Spend more time training your new employees, and be transparent that those who aren't incredibly proficient will be weeded out. explain on day one that its not 4 10s a week, it may be 4 12s or more.

review_title: Hard Work Environment... Unwilling to Adapt to Adapt to Change
pros: - Incredibly friendly staff who knew exactly what they were doing.
cons:
- I was hired during a transition period in Minnesota while SuperValu, (Where this chain was based) was being sold to a bigger, healthier chain (now fully transitioned) company we know as UNFI, so, what was hard, was that the people in my department knew what they were (kind of doing) but, coming in, as a BRAND-NEWcomer, everything was different, because something I may have learned as a Supervalu policy would have changed two days later as UNFi would have something a comptely different way.
Advice to Management
My advice to management would be this. I very much appreciate you hiring me. But, I asked EASILY five to ten times a day for guidance and I had to just sit in my cube waiting for assistance, because none of us knew what to do. So, what's hard, is that I really value the relationships, but Long-term, I think I should have kept looking, and I don't even remember a merger being talked about in our interview. That's something that maybe you should ask a potential employee about. Like saying "we're in a major transition phase" do you feel comfortable not know what do to at times? Etc.
Helpfu
advice_to_mgmt:
My advice to management would be this. I very much appreciate you hiring me. But, I asked EASILY five to ten times a day for guidance and I had to just sit in my cube waiting for assistance, because none of us knew what to do. pros: I love the culture and the values! I'm proud to work from a company that feeds and supports our communities. There is a high value on philanthropy, sustainability, associate development and engagement. UNFI invests in and is committed to showing employee appreciation - From lunches and meal kits for our associates working in the DC to handing out turkeys for Thanksgiving and fundraising picnics for our Associate Relief Fund - there is a genuine care and recognition for the work the team does.
cons:
There is a lot going on right now and we are still growing together as one company. We've made huge strides, but there have been herculean efforts to do so, which has required longer work days. At times I feel there is an expectation for perfection and to get everything done in an unreasonable amount of time.

review_title: Great to work for a company that cares
pros: I joined UNFI about 6 months ago as part of a personal career change. I was really nervous, not only to start at a new company, but a new career/industry altogether and UNFI has been unbelievably supportive in my new venture. Not only is everyone so nice and friendly and willing to lend a helping hand, but I also feel supported by my team and the learning tools and programs that have been put in place for me to take advantage of. It's great to hear company values like Delivering Together and Doing the Right Thing worked into decision making processes. And I couldn't be more proud of what this company is doing for their associates to keep us safe and engaged during this Pandemic. They were proactive in their approach and putting safety first. I hope to grow and develop with this company for a while!
cons:
Due to the acquisition of Supervalu, UNFI is working through the IT/Technical aspects of merging the two companies onto 1 set of systems, which as I'm sure everyone know, does not happen over night. Since the review requires I put something in the con's, I suppose my only 'con' at the moment is that it's slightly clunky trying to navigate a different system than potentially a teammate in a different location is navigating, however they've made significant strides already in integrating, and this is only temporary as the company further and further integrates onto one system.
Helpfu

pros: The pay was decent at 18.45$ an hour. It's not worth the money they pay though, due to how they treat employees and the complete inconsistency. To make one thing clear I never write reviews, but my experience here was so dreadful I want to help people steer away from pursuing this occupation.
cons:
The amount of work you put on your body is enormous. They work off of a seniority first basis which really screws new guys over on the daily. The schedule is constantly changing, so don't plan anything for your "set off days". You will not get a weekend off until at least 10 years in. There is no growth in the company. You will be order selecting for the 30+ years you work. Which is going to ruin your body. I really can't think of much positive to say.
Advice to Management
Supervisors are actually great. Upper management is where you tend to fail. Communication between the ranks is crucial and is a huge downfall at your company. Respect also goes a long way.

Turn over is extremely high since the merger so don’t get too comfortable with your co workers. I wouldn’t recommend any position at UNFI and there’s hundreds of others that would say the same. Advice to Management
I'd like to note that although I kept quiet about what happened during my internship at SuperValu when they got bought out by UNFI, there were so many inappropriate things that happened that I wish I knew were HR reportable at my time of employment. It was never communicated to me what types of things were considered harassment and as a college student, I was unfamiliar with what was and wasn't HR reportable. 

 I do not recommend any college student to take on an internship with this company. This company brought me down career-wise by ripping up every shred of confidence I had left. As management won't care to teach you anything useful about the business, will make you do stereotypical "intern" office work, and will treat you poorly by talking down to you. Your time here will be wasted surrounded by unhappy people who don't have the time nor want to teach you anything insightful.

My advice to management: be open-minded to new ideas, train your employees properly so you don't have to micromanage them, & keep inappropriate comments to yourself. Your interns take on this job to learn, grow, and scope out your company for future job opportunities, treat them as your equals, not as kids who should be doing all of your "grunt" work.
Helpful (3

pros: Coworkers and my direct supervisors have been awesome, only thing that keeps me here to be honest.
cons:
Where do I start? This company bought my company out and it's been nothing but downhill since. UNFI is clearly a company that does not value their employees, they see us as numbers on a sheet of paper. The CIO showed up in our offices in December and pretty much lied to our face about what to expect for layoffs, all while touting how "transparent" he is being. 2 days later people started getting 30 day notices. Keep in mind this is maybe 10 days or so before Christmas. If this isn't enough to tell you how poor the top leadership is... keep reading.

The concept of working from home is rocket science to these people. The CEO and the CIO value the optics of seeing people sitting in their desks over actual productivity. They don't know how a modern IT shop works.

The most childish part of this leadership is the CEO's award he gives out quarterly. You'd think an award that comes from the CEO would sound like an award that comes from the CEO and would look good on a resume right? Nope, he hands out the Mr. Pickles award. It's the laughing stock in our office. Apparently there is a deli in RI called Mr. Pickles and the CEO had really good service there once so he decided to make an award out of it. Because a deli that doesn't even exist in my state is somehow motivating?
Advice to Management
If you want the credit for being transparent you should actually try to allign your actions around your words. The CEO and CIO (as well as certain VPs) have zero credibility because you told us you'd be transparent and your actions were as transparent as a brick wall. No one trusts you nor takes you seriously. 

When you show up and start laying people off, the adult thing to do is to tell us what to expect. Instead you showed up, shrugged your shoulders and said everything would be just peachy. 

Might I remind you, that as an employer you are competing for my services. You might be a big fish in a small pond in RI, but in my state you are a small fish in a very big pond, and we have plenty of options. If you value your talent (and let's be honest your actions indicate you don't) you'll make a complete 180 on your behavior. I'm not holding my breath.

review_title: Not the best as it use to be
pros: You can accrue 96 hours of PTO the first 2 years and then third year you get 117 hours of PTO, you have a flexible work schedule, and when you go through any family emergency the management can be very understanding. cons:
Not enough diversity, There is not one person who has any ethnicity in management in the whole building. There is no room for advancement. I have seen Co-workers work together to get someone to quit or get fired with little no mediation between HR or Management, It is not a team setting environment so do not talk AT ALL. and pay is not the best 0.50 annual raises. The medical plan is H O R R I B L E. There is a lot changing in the negative with or new buy out. I use to love this job a lot but things seem to be changing for the worst. Management is not transparent AT ALL which can have you blind sided.
Advice to Management
I would say to try and create a happy, healthy work environment by celebrating diversity and team work. Have your employees cooperate with one another and create events to get to no one another. I have a guy that started in my department and its been 1 year and still haven't been introduced to him once. Always be transparent and open to your team about their concerns and their growth. please please give your new people good trainers that are patient and last but not least give everyone the same chance to train the same way, don't just assume someone would not understand.

pros: Company culture, training, people, values
cons:
They say you don't have to complete the 4 month probationary period if you reach the set numbers for two weeks in a row. I met those numbers in my first two weeks of work, and have continued to reach them. I received an offer letter for a full-time position and even PTO. I still have yet to have been brought on as a full time employee - MEANING, they send me home when there isn't enough work (everyday). I had to use my PTO days last week to ensure a decent paycheck for my family. THIS IS RIDICULOUS. No employee should have to use their PTO just to ensure an 8hr work day. I work on average 4hrs/day. Some days, I drive the 40 minutes to work, and get told there isn't work and am sent home. I have spoken to my union steward AND superintendent about the issue and have continued to be told that I am next on the list to be hired on. This shows very poor management. If I wanted to work a part-time position, I would have applied somewhere that was offering that. Instead, I applied here to work full time + overtime (what was promised) and am really working a mere 25hrs/week if I'm lucky.
Advice to Management
Be upfront and honest with people in your job postings and on-boarding. They should know the hours they will be working so they can plan accordingly (your workers have bills to pay and families to provide for!!!!)

cons:

Do not question authority, the way things are done, or why processes are inefficient. If you haven’t been here for 15 years, expect to be talked down on, bullied by upper management, and have work continuously added to your plate for no recognition, promotion, or additional pay. The phrase “the better you get at your job, the more work you get” is a favorite amongst leaders and is very true. Become good at your job and you will be given more and more work with no additional pay.

cons:

Advice to Management
Let it go. While I understand the volatility of the food industry, your constricting policies on current employees are going to cost you long-term. Advice to Management
Advocate more for the people you supervise, upper management is taking to much from them( no Christmas bonus, seriously? Pay people well if you are asking them to break their back for the company. Your company never had a problem hiring people until you messed with the incentive program and added the stupid points system. Also the new warehouse management systems that you are putting into your warehouses might have its benefits if you view the warehouse from behind your desk but to the people that actually use it everyday, it was a big waste of money and made their jobs harder. Maybe you should have asked your employees what they thought about the system, or would that have been to considerate?

The drivers who work odd hours and drive for miles and miles, and the order selectors who lift thousands of pounds per day. I love the focus on corporate social responsibility and philanthropy efforts. 

The benefits are pretty good and the wellness program ensures lower cost of premiums. The tuition reimbursement program is amazing to continue your education. The product discount is also a very nice benefit.

The equipment and facilities for the most part were very good. Ergonomic standing desk stations, new trucks, and decent lift trucks. The company events and prizes were good.

Top notch Transportation Department, Safety Team, Supervisors, and promotion opportunities from within.

The HR department kept managers consistent for the most part.
cons:
The region's senior leadership team would make the ground shake when walking through the facility. The fear that was bred into the facility to execute tasks or be removed was heart breaking. There was no inspiration, no motivation and definitely no appreciation from them towards staff members. Frequently resources were restricted, expectations increased, and power was used to manipulate the local management team to carry out dirty deeds or apply unnecessary pressure. The current General Managers plays into this cabal of senior leaders flawlessly.

Order Selectors beware - Mandatory 16 hour shifts were frequent only with the expectation to show up the next morning and do it all over again. No plans were ever discussed to improve the working conditions for the warehouse. 

Always hiring! You can always find a job here due to the astonishing turnover. This is not sustainable and shareholders carry the expense of costly turnover. Why do people seek to work somewhere else? They want to be treated like people and have positive relationships with their managers, to be respected, and have work life balance.
Advice to Management
Understand what is actually going on in your facility by going there and actually getting out of your office to speak with people. Start fresh by finding new leaders that value their people on a personal level and remove the toxic group of non-value added untouchables. Focus on collaboration not isolation and you will find your employees will be more engaged, and excited to work hard each day.
Helpful (7
advice_to_mgmt: Understand what is actually going on in your facility by going there and actually getting out of your office to speak with people. Start fresh by finding new leaders that value their people on a personal level and remove the toxic group of non-value added untouchables. Focus on collaboration not isolation and you will find your employees will be more engaged, and excited to work hard each day.

review_title: Don’t t even THINK about trying to get an IT job here!
pros: There are no pros. None whatsoever. If there ever were any, they’re gone now. The company store does have a good selection of breakfast and lunch items at a reasonable price. The fresh fruit is absolutely tremendous,
cons:
Most of IT management from managers on up are splendid examples of the Peter Principle in action, or rather inaction. Any creativity or free thinking of any kind gets quickly squashed and buried. Micromanagement to the sub-atomic level is in full force. Trying to get information on how or why systems are designed will usually get you one of two answers, The most popular answer is “I don’t know.” The runner up is most often “Well, that’s the way we’ve always done it!” New employees get no trading at all, so it’s either sink or swim. Forget about a training budget- it just does not exist. Turnover is so horrible that it’s laughable. Anyone that you run across that’s even mildly competent is planning to leave. Guaranteed. Retention is definitely not part of the game plan. They are more than willing to let what good people they have leave then replace them with the first warm body that shows up, usually in the form of a contractor. Far too many contractors in my opinion. The contractors I’ve work with there however, are for the most part amazing. Multiple advanced degrees seem to be very common. A good Education is very important in other countries, more so than in the US. These guys (and gals) are very hard workers.
Advice to Management
Relinquish your position in the company and leave. Hire replacements from outside. If you are part of the management team and are reading this and are thinking that I may be referring to you, you’re right.

Local 77 union staff are easy to work with and make good working partners. There is a genuine sense that management team wants to make positive changes in the workplace but is frustrated. The HR department should all be given a medals. I just don't know how they did it.
cons:
Teamsters Local 120 union is impossible to work with. They shout obscenities and try to push their agenda through intimidation tactics. Union employees have forgotten that their paychecks say "SUPERVALU" and not "Local 120 Teamsters". Budgets are extra tight (mostly because of the excessive spending on overtime and unavoidable waste that must continue due to a bad local 120 union contract) so pushing new initiatives for improvements is very difficult.
Advice to Management
Stand your ground with the Local 120 on June 1, 2018 and get your facility back. When running the numbers to see if it is cost effective to have a strike or force them out you should also make sure to quantify the employee turn over costs from dealing with out of control teamsters there. Change the culture to one that promotes synergy of all and not entitlement of a few.

review_title: Good but not Great Place to Work
pros: Competitive Salary, Friendly Work Environment, medical wellness incentives
cons:
Care more about retailers than employees; insurance deductibles are a little high; poor management; overworked and underpaid; exempt employees receive no incentives when required to work over 40 hours; pay everyone on the same level but not everyone is given the same amount of work; treated unfairly.
Advice to Management
If you're going to pay everyone at the same rate, give everyone the same amount of work. Do not over work an employee just because they have more knowledge than others. Treat everyone fairly. No business can operate at its full potential without organization. Have more knowledge than the people you manage or you should not be in a management position.

pros:
*Good pay
* Car allowance
* Benefits, paid holidays and vacation time
* Some locations are team oriented and easy to work with.
*Semi flexable. Start as early or late as you want. However later starts make longer days. 
* Fairly easy but very physical
* stores send weekly reports. You may be mentioned in a positive way if there are no issues in the store. Of couse they could also just put " no issues" which is good too.
cons:
* mispicks, mispicks and more mispicks. It's out of control.
* orders don't always arrive when scheduled
*Some locations can be challanging to work with
* Reps are often blamed for warehouse errors such as items not coming in or mispicks.
* training could be better across the board.
* Unfi mgmt could be more supportive when problems arise. Often immediate supervisors are nonchalant about issues in stores and just not available or supportive when needed. Trust me talking to my boss is the last thing I want to do so if I'm calling then there's a issue.
* stores seem to be confused about what we can and cannot give credits on. Actually they just seem confused in general about most of the contract.
* stores send weekly reports which means if you refused to do something that you're not supposed to do anyway but the store thinks you are because either they choose to ignore the contract or they are confused about the contract. You will probably be mentioned in the report and not in a positive way. 
* can't see what was ordered or dollar amount to cross check or determine commission.
Advice to Management
Train your employees including supervisors. Get the mispicks under control! There are holes on the shelf partly because of excessive mispicks. Please make sure the stores we service understand the outlines of the contract. They should know what reps can and cannot do and what we are and are not responsible for. Stores are saying yes you are supposed to do x,y,z and Unfi is saying no you aren't. The breakdown in communication makes the job difficult when it doesn't have to be. Work out the kinks and everything will be good.
Helpfu

pros:
People were great; both coworkers and direct managers were supportive and friendly, and just generally good people. Appreciated a job well done, made coming to work each day a pleasant experience.

When I started,
cons:
Starting salary was good, but "merit" raises (typically just 2% COLA) were a joke. Benefits were extremely lackluster for a Fortune 500, and 401(k) matching is a joke (just 1%).

Upper management is a revolving door of stale ideas and failure, perennially forced out and then replaced with another member of the old guard who insists on putting their friends in high-level positions and then making the same mistakes.
Advice to Management
If you want to attract, develop, and keep younger talent, you need to help them grow (both professional and financial incentives need to improve).

You need to be affirmatively family-friendly, because tomorrow's managers with years of experience are today's employees with young kids, and you need them to stick around and grow in the industry.

Stop being so stingy and greedy. Telling your employees you don't have money for merit raises while a short-time exec gets a multi-million dollar payout is just a slap in the face. Reward hard work and talent.

pros: Lots of opportunity within the company. Tons of areas to choose from for work. Great benefits. Daytime hours without weekends. Paid holidays. Some work from home opportunities. A lot of great people work within this company.
cons:
Some departments have issues. I reported things to HR, which left the building and came back to me from another employee. I was fired six months later for supposedly not knowing my job, despite working there for 4.5 years without any poor reviews or conduct issues. My manager blatantly lied about the things I reported to HR, when confronted about them. I was doing three people's jobs at the time due to other employees leaving and not being replaced. I learned a huge lesson about the purposes of HR.
Advice to Management
The higher ups need to look into the departments who are firing long-term employees who have been there for 4 or more years. I watched several other people that this "Director" just didn't like, get put on performance improvement plans, and then be fired. If you are put on a performance improvement plan, chances are you will be let go at the end, in this particular group. Don't get me wrong, I find PIP's to be a great tool for improvement, but the group I was in, used them to play dirty. You should know that I was told I had a lawsuit, but I did not file because despite that small group in the company, I still love the rest of Supervalu.

pros:
- Commitment to the environment
- Majority of the employees are helpful and friendly
cons:
- Too reliant on technology without really understanding how to use it
- failure to update systems to accommodate the size and volume of the business
- Penalize you for any health issues you may have with how much you have to pay for health insurance (they term it reward those who make the choices for healthy living which if that's the case, then the base cost for health insurance is too high)
- Too many in management keep secrets and/or don't have a clue about what is happening
- Lack of trust of what anyone in management tells you
- Lack in the ability of management who often are elevated because of favoritism than for ability
Advice to Management
A major overhaul so that reporting can be done across the entire country with one system instead of the split system currently used which don't communicate with each other should be a first priority. Second, business units should be tied to each other horizontally instead of the current vertical model which compartmentalizes too many projects and results in business units working against each other, competing programs, lack of knowledge of where to go to get information and/or results, etc. Third staff to realistically accommodate the workload instead of overloading everyone and be satisfied with half done work.

review_title: Be careful!! High turnover and heavy workload
pros: Decent (not great) benefits and volunteer opportunities
cons:
Too much work, no support from management, high school like environment regarding rumors and promotions, lack of teamwork and respect, difficult to communicate with other departments. HR and Management are two faced and don't have your back. At first, I thought this was a good opportunity but then realized your just a minion in the company and hold no value. I worked my butt off for my customers and felt as though I was the only one who cared at the company. I went to upper management several times for serious problems and got little or no help. The employees they hire for the warehouse and customer care are not professional and don't care. Supervisor is inexperienced, unintelligent, didn't care and only did things to make herself look better. Manager ALWAYS had their door shut. Very high turnover, lack of training and no room for advancement. At least 3 people fired or quit a month in one department alone. Also high turnover in HR which isn't a good sign. Attendance policy extremely strict and they will make no exceptions no matter how good of an employee you are. This place will give you experience but I wouldn't stay longer than a year or two.
Advice to Management
Focus on employees, provide more support from management, hire more people to lighten the work load, change the attendance policy, make it easier to communicate across departments, Reward hard work, more focus on customers. I heard this place used to be great but clearly is headed in the wrong direction.
Helpful (6

review_title: Not the company it used to be.
pros: Pay and benefits are above average. Office layout is nice. Location in Providence is very well done.
cons:
Beware of this place!

Executive management has been in disarray for the last two years and this is not changing anytime soon. Turnover is very high under the new "leadership". HR is so weak it is laughable. I would not recommend this company to anyone at this point. To say the atmosphere is toxic would be the understatement of the 21st century. 

If you decide to go ahead and interview anyway, take notice of the demeanor of the employees. This should be your first sign that this is not a good idea, no matter what the pay. Second indication should be the transient nature of the very top leadership. Inquire as to how often the highest level is actually present at the Corporate HQ. I doubt they will tell you the truth, but, the CEO spends about 10 days there per Quarter. No wonder why there is such disorganization. Third, ask about turnover. They probably will not tell you the truth here either but people disappear from this organization without explanation. Fourth, ask them about their IT "systems" and watch their eyes glaze over in fear. Performing even the most simple tasks is an exercise in futility. Lastly, do your research online as to how the senior leadership has taken care of themselves (compensation) at the expense of lower level employees recently. 

After all of this if you decide to go here anyway, good luck as you will need it. Don't walk, RUN away as fast as possible.
Advice to Management
Actually, I have no advice. Senior leadership is so far gone I don't think anything can fix it short of a total house cleaning or sale of the business,
Helpful (18
advice_to_mgmt: Actually, I have no advice. Senior leadership is so far gone I don't think anything can fix it short of a total house cleaning or sale of the business,

review_title: Gap between pay and skills becomes depressing
pros: Hands down the best group of people I've ever worked with. I made life long friends here and learned so much. This is a great company to get your foot in the door and develop skills from the ground up. There is very much of a collaborative environment where you are encouraged to ask questions and push your limits. But really, at the end of the day what made it for me was the team. They made coming into work something I always looked forward to.
cons:
Where to start? For starters, the atmosphere and cultural decline. There were multiple layoffs which makes a noticeable impact on moral. Teams were expected to move at the same pace while lacking in resources. Individuals were often times taking on responsibilities of multiple roles while being told from leadership that working 80+ hours was expected. Benefits have been slashed year by year. At this point there's an ongoing joke on when the free Thanksgiving turkeys will be removed from the benefits program. Raises are minimal at best and have dwindled every single year. Top preforming teammates won't even get close to cost of living at this point while being told we should count our blessing that we even have a job. There's been talk of removing yearly merit increases all together. Once you sign on with a certain wage, you'll be locked in, even if you get a promotion as they're only allowed to increase pay buy x %. While I mentioned earlier that it's a great learning opportunity, the gap between skills and pay as the years crawl by becomes more and more, to the point where an employee could easily double their pay should the move to a different company. 

Pay and benefits aside, there's also the day to day life. Procedures are minimal and documentation is close to none as most teams are expected to move at a pace that simply doesn't allow for the time to document anything. Deadlines and expectations are set by executive level leadership without an understanding of effort involved, leaving the actual team scrambling to meet deadlines to avoid being marked as failures. The work is almost sometimes unrealistic and teams often times create products that are sub-par due to the lack of support from the higher ups. Not being able to finish a single project, or worse, delivering a product that is less than what the team could produce due to unrealistic expectations is demoralizing. 

Promotion won't happen either, unless you know the right people and are of the right personality type. Show interest and they will "train" you for years on end, giving you managerial tasks under the excuse of prepping you for the role while you maintain an associate title and salary.
Advice to Management
Provide a budget for training and please, stand up to executives when they're demanding unrealistic goals from the team with an unrealistic deadline. At least consult with your team before you commit.
Helpful (14
advice_to_mgmt: Provide a budget for training and please, stand up to executives when they're demanding unrealistic goals from the team with an unrealistic deadline. At least consult with your team before you commit.

review_title: RUN AWAY! Run far far away!
pros: Nice office building.. thats it.
cons:
I accepted an offer for an administrative position. I had 2 other offers I turned down for this job. I took the job because it would be an easy commute for me. They only offer 5 holidays per year which is pathetic in my opinion. The vacation time is also lacking. I was hired and before starting I let management know I had 2 previously scheduled days I needed off for medical appointments, they said it would be fine. Unfortunately the early am before my 2nd day of work, there was a fire in the basement of my house. I called my manager to let him know I would be out on my 2nd day because of the fire, I got his voicemail. 

I then received a phone call at 11 am that same morning telling me that he was terminating my employment! I was fired for having a FIRE in my home! THIS COMPANY DOES NOT CARE FOR ITS EMPLOYEES. I was treated with zero compassion or empathy. I was told I was being let go because management didn't like that I had two future days I would need off - even though it was approved before I started. The 2nd reason he said I was being let go was because he thought I was "living closer" - I had just bought a home in a different town then what was listed on my resume. I think firing someone based on where they live is discriminatory? Those are the reasons he used but its clear he was annoyed because I called out my 2nd day. I'm sorry my house caught fire!!! I was there one day and in that one day it was easy to see many employees are not happy at this company. The fact that I was let go for having a fire speaks VOLUMES about the culture at this company. RUN!
Advice to Management
Unfortunate things happen to good people every day! It is disgusting that you punish them for unfortunate events.
Helpful (16
advice_to_mgmt: Unfortunate things happen to good people every day! It is disgusting that you punish them for unfortunate events.

pros: The staff and customers were typically nice people, and the computer training was efficient. It was also convenient to be able to let customers shop so you have time to finish prescriptions.
cons:
The staff did not always appreciate their employees or convey important messages to others. (They often yelled at employees for changes they never told employees about, etc.) Extra work is often given and it can be a challenge to leave on time. If you use their training program and become certified, it doesn't make a difference. The wages are the lowest I've seen for pharmacy technicians and there is no room for advancement. Extra work is not appreciated, but expected. If they are short on technicians, they expect hired technicians to pick up the extra slack, and are not always respectful of the time it takes to study for classes.
Advice to Management
Pharmacy technicians are hard to hold onto when they are paid extremely low wages and there's no room for advancement. I would suggest more frequent raises and to create positions such a 'lead technician' or something along those lines. I would also suggest creating a message board to easily communicate any changes in the pharmacy.

pros: Benefits and PTO. Commitment to sustainable solutions and giving back to the community. Company encourages a healthy lifestyle, fresh fruit daily. Strong core values. Culture is relaxed, some flexibility to work remotely at manager's discretion. Opportunity to meet and learn from motivated, smart people. Bright, modern office space.
cons:
Company grew too quickly through a series of acquisitions resulting in too many business systems that are archaic and cumbersome. Morale is tense due to recent company-wide layoffs as a result of lost business due to poor customer management. Not enough resources, everyone is completely overloaded with work, performance expectations are unrealistic. Mid level management is a joke, director level associates with TERRIBLE communication skills are the norm. Zero support despite months and months asking for help. Poor training, SOPs are inconsistent if they even exist. Annual merit increases are a meager 3% if you're lucky, amounting to a bump of only pennies a day. Little recognition for a job well done, lots of scolding for not pulling your weight. Very few opportunities for corporate growth or development. Favoritism is very high - expect to eat, sleep and breathe UNFI if you want to get ahead.
Advice to Management
Streamline the business systems. Make smart business decisions so that dedicated, valuable people don't lose their jobs. Hire more resources; it's crucial to setting your employees for success to produce efficiently instead of running on fumes. Inspect and replace mid level managers who consistently miss the mark and are just unprofessional. Get rid of the dead weight slackers, even if they've been around for 10-20 years, you know who they are. Ask your people what they need to be successful, then actually follow through and support them.

pros: I enjoy working with this company because the atmosphere is very fun and busy. The customers are great and my co-workers are very nice. We have a policy that states we must be professional, friendly and respectful towards other employees. Our management and HR within our store is very supportive. I really enjoy the overall atmosphere here.
cons:
On the flip side, hours for part timers can be difficult to maintain as there are always new cashiers being hired and the hours are spread amongst everyone. And getting full time is near impossible as a cashier. There are a few "old timers" from back in the day when Supervalu used to hire full time. But they're a "dying breed". Other than that, I find this to be a fun place to work.
Advice to Management
The idea of management should be all about mentoring and promoting and moving up. I don't see that happening under the current management. They don't want to lose any good employees. So they are not prone to training and promoting. My last store director was all about mentoring. His goal was to raise up leaders and ship them out. He found joy in doing that. I think that is what keeps a company thriving and current! No fear of the future. Living in the now. I miss that management style. Especially since I have been trying to get trained for quite a while now so I may be promoted. It is not happening for fear of the manager losing their job to a fresh face who costs a little less to keep on board. I am currently looking for a new job that is full time with benefits because of this reason. I have been in my current position for about five years.
Although the career opportunities are great at this company, it really depends on the management at the store you work at. So my ratings below are based on individual store management style.
I have not had direct contact with the CEO of this company so I have to review for him.

employee_status: Systems Analyst in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: flex work schedule was good
cons:
I was part of a full location lay off at the end of the great recession. Having received assurances that if we found work before our severance end date they would work with us on paying our severance, I started searching for work. I received an offer for a job that fit my experience well and put in my notice. Even though I had put in 20 years of blood, sweat and tears for American Stores/Albertsons/Supervalu and I had completed the turnover of my duties as specified in the severance agreement, HR and or IT made a determination that they could decline to pay my severance because I found another job. I have since learned that at least one other individual who left before his severance date was paid his severance. Also, after declining my severance they had the nerve to call me a couple of months after I left and ask for my help with a program problem. Unbelievable!!!
Advice to Management
Follow the golden rule.

review_title: UNFI Rich in Profits, Poor in Service and Store Support
pros: Good profit sharing, decent benefits, good team meetings and training with brokers and manufacture reps when you seek it out.
cons:
Executive Level management annually beat their chests bragging 'bout year over year channel sales growth and increasing shareholder profits....despite all this growth each year. we have not increased the size of our customer service, sales, operations and marketing teams at all instead they pile it on employee workloads with a take-it-or leave-it smirk.... We've lost several key account chains by ignoring requests from Store Executives, Owners, Myself and other Veteran Territory Mangers of repeated service issues. 

When will UNFI Executives realize we need to stop sitting on profits and invest in the company and our stores by hiring additional sales, customer service and store support members?
 
Operations teams from routing, inventory control, credit department and many of our recently hired drivers really act as if they don't care and do not believe in customer service?
Advice to Management
Listen to your employees and hire additional sales and store support managers. Or we will continue loosing more profitable business that can be serviced much better by our competitors.

review_title: Amazing benefits, decent 401k enrollment, and room to grow in the company.
pros:
Employee benefits are fantastic, UNFI also provides a 401k plan with matching contribution of $.50 on every dollar, up to 8%. Basic life insurance coverage provided free of cost as a UNFI selector. Paid volunteer hours for select events. As well as incentives of up to $4.50 more per hour if conditions met. 
Lots of overtime availability.
cons:
There point system can be difficult to deal with especially in first 90 days. 
You leave when the trucks are loaded if you work in loading and product selecting. My hours are supposed to be 2 P. M. - 12 A. M. But most days it ends up being 1-3 A.M. 
High turn over rate which leads to a constant flow of new employees who have little to no experience. This tends to add a lot of time onto our nights.
Advice to Management
Mandatory pallet stacking training for at least first 2¬3 days of new employees. Without much proper training I see a lot of newbie selectors get frustrated right away and eventually leave completely. Be honest at the beginning of the shift, don't sugar coat how long the day looks go be.

cons:
Disconnect between how management and developers communicate - non-technical managers often hand down projects/deadlines that are contradictory to feedback/estimates delivered by development teams.

The attitude towards IT projects has been stuck under a "quickest, cheapest" mentality for a long time, though this is fortunately changing. There is a mountain of code debt that has been accumulating for years, to the point development on new projects is often stalled by forgotten business logic and back-end service caveats.

Few perks for employees - on-site cafeteria, but bring your own k-cups since you can't even expect free coffee here. Employee on-boarding process through HR left out a lot of information, and any questions on HR processes have to be answered via 800-number.
Advice to Management
A lot of new talent has come in, with tried-and-true ideas tested at other companies. Ignoring their feedback will not keep them there long.

review_title: Too many changes in transportation dept that are bad. And the trucks and equipment very below average
pros: There are some pros working with unfi they often have companies picnics and give out bonuses quarterly
cons:
You start at $20 hr but you won't have the check to show for it if you have a daily route. They keep taken from and adding to your run without most time you knowing anything about it until you get your invoices. And also if you don't mind doing dolly work this is the place for you. But the Equipment is the most pathetic the the industry I ever saw; they do not take care of their trucks and electric pallet Jack's you don't know from day to day what you gonna have. And if you get your equipment I tell you DO YOURSELF A FAVOR CHECK YOUR EQUIPMENT before leaving on your run if not you will have a very bad day. And also depending on your run you might touch nothing if you have dock deliveries but 90 percent of the time you be breaking down multiple pallets that can vary in sizes that can take some time to do. Oh yeah one more thing the trucks are govern at 62 mph; now if like slow trucks then it's won't be a problem for you
Advice to Management
Hey Management just try to work with the drivers instead of against them by letting us voice our opinions and at least meeting them half way rather than care about yourselves and your profits.

Advice to Management
You barter in goods, specifically food goods which is probably the 2nd oldest trade. There isn't a lot of innovation selling a banana. You either sell it cheap or have a nice store to mark up the price hoping people will still buy that same Dole banana at a higher cost when they can walk across the street and find it cheaper. You aren't Whole Foods and you aren't Wal-Mart. Figure that out and price accordingly.

pros: Nice coworkers in certain departments, easy going in certain departments. The company has good roots, and has solid executive leaders. This company is here for the long haul.
cons:
The design work is not fun to work on, excel sheets, data merge and production are 95 percent of the job. Very little creative work, even in the good departments. Not enough time to manage projects. Company is business to business, so design isn't appreciated or fairly compensated. Start pay for designers and photographers is horrible, not a livable wage. The design work is unattractive, lacking in concept, and the final design approval comes from business managers who have terrible design judgement. Working from home isn't excepted, company in general is outdated in this area by 10 years, they don't even have meet me meetings. Caveman process, when it comes to day to day business practice. Oh and the benefits are poor compared to other local companies.

Pay a livable wage, follow the national average based on the area we live in. Stop using a one company philosophy to save money. We can't afford to live here with these terrible salaries.

review_title: Great company mission - extremely bad management - IT a disaster
pros: Fast growing company linked to Whole Foods (40% of business) and the growing organic and natural field. Staff below upper management is dedicated and skilled. UNFI has a strong commitment to the community and supports lots of volunteerism by employees.
cons:
Upper management is poorly suited for this fast growing company - most are learning on the job. IT is a complete disaster - old legacy systems, poor infrastructure, constant fire-fighting issues that result in significant unpaid work nights and weekends by many, many people. In my 4 years there, lots of major projects across IT depts. that took lots of effort beyond regular duties, and most ultimately ended up being cancelled mid-stream. CIO doesn't have a clue (came from A&P after being there 37 years) - VP level in IT replaced twice in 2 years - confused priorities and little planning. This is NOT a company where you can grow your IT career - no commitment to training or using new technology. Plenty of other and much better Fortune 500 companies in RI to pursue a technical job.
Advice to Management
My advice is to the Board of Directors - take a comparative look at the experience and skills of UNFI executive management against other similar sized companies with similar growth. You'll see your executives rank poorly and are ill-prepared to grow this company properly.
Helpful (16
advice_to_mgmt: My advice is to the Board of Directors - take a comparative look at the experience and skills of UNFI executive management against other similar sized companies with similar growth. You'll see your executives rank poorly and are ill-prepared to grow this company properly.

review_title: Where is the Arthur T of UNFI? Who in Executive Mngmt cares for the Employees?
pros:
Discounts on natural and organic food but you need to buy a case of most items. 
Encouraged to volunteer in the community and to give blood at the blood drive.
Workers are dedicated and hard working. Some managers are really wonderful. Nice HR staff.
cons:
Cog in the machine. Huge machine. 
Horrible Penalty points in place. Good employees miss out on parent/teacher conferences -- basic doctor appts -- can't leave work early for children's school events -- employees feel they have to get to work through huge snow storms --- leaving work early is a whole point penalty. If you are late you will get a 1/2 point. You get two points for being sick on a Monday. You are 'awarded' a point for being sick on T, W, Th or Friday. They have employees coming to work sick or even with the flu so as not to get too many points. Good employees are fired b/c of their 'points'. NOT family friendly as you are made to feel you can't be out for your illness or your child's illness. I know many good people driving to work too fast so as not to get points. Moral is poor. 
Positions are often limited to a very set boundaries. Not intellectually challenged.
Some manager are good but many managers are not qualified and are micro-managing.
Advice to Management
1. 2. and 3. Get rid of the penalty system. Salaried folks are treated far better than the lowly hourly. 
4. promote good managers that care about their employees. 
5. Allow some flexible schedules for parents of young children
6. Please go back to the 'good old days' when you cared MORE for employees and not only about the BOARD OF DIRECTORS.
Helpful (10

1. 2. and 3. Get rid of the penalty system. Salaried folks are treated far better than the lowly hourly. 
4. promote good managers that care about their employees.

review_title: Stock and replenish wholesale merchandise, and work on post orders by breaking down the pallets and printing labels.
pros: Stocking merchandise is quite easy. Scanning the labels to prepare for inputting the "pick line" or "back shelf" for that item.
cons:
Post orders are difficult to work with. Because breaking down the items from the pallet can sometimes require reorganizing the pallet for bulk quantities, and searching for extra U-boats for more minimal quantities.
Advice to Management
If an employee is good on one task (like stocking), but is bad at another task (like post orders); don't have that employee laid off. Just have an employee continue on a task he/she is good at that task.

pros: Shoe voucher. That's it.
cons:
Company values are a complete illusion. You work 12 - 14 hours every day; if you're scheduled to work an 8 hour shift the minimum is 10 hours and often more due to call-ins. No one really wants to stay here, the turnover is obvious. I hate this place and have never seen so many disgruntled workers unhappy for the same reasons.
Advice to Management
Hire people in groups larger than 3 for Order Selectors. Easily more than 30 of the people I started with six months ago are gone. Do NOT allow Michael Funk to hit the streets and tell people things that are mostly untrue. $17/hr was true for the first 20 or so people initially hired to get the word out, then the starting pay was $13.25. Why do that? People are burned out so quickly here. 
 Nice to see Funk living the dream in his 6,500 square foot house. Not the hippie I thought but perception is everything.

review_title: A challenge that will make or break you.
pros:
-Start out pay is good; 15.20 an hour (once qualifications are met - 16.20 an hour).
- Great place to work for any person that is up for challenge, change, and motivation. 
- The goal (the motivation/requisition of an order selector) is to meet the daily/weekly average. There is an incentive bonus added to ones overall pay that is based on your weekly score. Minimum score requirement for the week is a 95%.
- There are tons of opportunities to grow, learn new things, and work you're way up. 
- Supervalu is one of the top highest in revenue grocery distributors in the U.S. This assures it's employees of job security. 
- You basically work alone.
- Fast paced environment. There's not much time for chitchat or any drama.
- Guaranteed 40+ hours (as of right now) a week.
- Fellow employees are very cool and easy to get along with. I will say that Supervalu has done a great job in finding the people that they need to fulfill their requirements, but they also have done an even greater job in finding those who are compatible with others.
cons:
- Tough work environment. It is slightly dark, dreary, cold, and claustrophobic in the warehouse, but it comes with the turf. Keep in mind that it is an old warehouse.
- The perishable side needs a lot of work. The isles are confusing to new hires and it's on the verge of becoming a safety hazard. 
- Concrete floors are cracked and uneven; making it hard to keep product in place when commuting from isle to isle. 
- Long work days (good or bad; depending on the person's personal life). Overtime is often thrown at you last minute, as well as any mandated work days when extra help is needed. 
- Only 30 minutes for lunch. I really feel like the warehouse employees deserve an hour lunch break, especially on busy/overtime workdays. You start to feel like a robot after awhile, so I definitely think a non-mandatory/optional one hour reboot time could help improve work productivity.
Advice to Management
We need more people! Especially the youth. Remember that the younger generations are what make an old company grow even older. Please continue to make your employees happy just as you are and reassure them of their hard work and efforts more often. Be honest and upfront; do not sugar coat any economical issues (if there are any) that might hurt the company and it's employee's.
Helpfu
advice_to_mgmt:
We need more people! Especially the youth. Remember that the younger generations are what make an old company grow even older. Please continue to make your employees happy just as you are and reassure them of their hard work and efforts more often. review_title: Constantly Shrinking Company with a Revolving Door of Senior Management
cons:
antly Shrinking Company with a Revolving Door of Senior Management"
2.0
★★★★★
Current Employee - Business Systems Analyst in Eden Prairie, MN
Doesn't Recommend
Negative Outlook
Disapproves of CEO
I have been working at United Natural Foods full-time for more than 10 years
Pros
I can not think of a Pro.
Cons
Never Ending Layoffs, at least once a year. Shrinking sales every year for the past 6 years. Senior Management turnover is very high. Have cut everything possible in order to save costs - Even cut out supplying cups or napkins in break rooms. Eliminated Dividends, Salary Increases, 401K contributions last year. Shrinking IT Organization with no career opportunities. Could go on and on.
Advice to Management
Stop bringing in buddies from prior companies. Stop trying to make company profitable by Cutting Costs (hasn't worked for the past 7 years). Stop laying off employees every year. Implement a company contribution or a matching amount to the 401K plan. Hire more professional Senior Management. Come up with a plan to increase sales.

review_title: Once was great, now is terrible.
pros: Used to be the people. But they have cut the office work force and expect 1/3 of the people to be able to continue the same level and quality of work. Sometimes I get a thank you or a nice job.
cons:
Mostly everything. The people they bring in are all from MN or out of the company, they no longer promote from within. They reinstated merit raises for them to only be a slap in the face (ie. 12 cents, woo thanks for nothing). Been here almost a decade and I make next to nothing with no one in upper management listening or even caring. All about the bottom line now. No sense of personality or community. They hire in new, lazy Category Managers who expect everyone else to do their job for them. They also treat people like we should be greatful for the job. They should be greatful that all their lowest paid people do the most work.
Advice to Management
Take advantage of the people who have already been here for years, who are eager and willing to be promoted and who CARE. Stop paying people a wage they can't even live off of and stop expecting them to be HAPPY about it. You aren't doing anyone a favor.

cons:
The owner doesn't care about his employees, just cares about making money. I worked there for 12 years and moved up from stock clerk to co-manager over the years. I was pretty much promised by the general manager his position when he retired. About two months before he retired he informed me that they were hiring someone else. Then they promoted and transferred my assistant manager to another store as general manager. So it was like a big slap in the face.

Treat your employees like people and they will take care of your store. Don't treat them just like the dollar signs you see in your eyes.

If your not going to hire us on to full time, at least give us some time off, even if it's unpaid. You wonder why everyone calls in sick all the time.

review_title: Still a long way to go
pros: Company is back to what it was before the Albertson's acquisition which could be a good thing because it can know be more focused on their wholesale business and Save A Lot (which was its strength previously) while it tries to figure out retail.
cons:
They still haven't figured out how to be a better retailer and they're starting to price themselves out of the wholesale business as they focus more on hitting margin while sales decline. They've cut back staff so deeply at banner and region headquarters and are spread so thin that they struggle to get just the basic activities done let alone implement improved strategies and programs.
Advice to Management
Start treating people like an asset. You can't keep expecting 60 - 70 hours every week with no raises or 401k match and no end in sight and think you're going to improve results long term.

review_title: Miserable experience. Veterans do not like outsiders and do whatever is necessary to push them out.
pros: The lower level employees are the greatest. Management needs to realize what a great workforce they have and treat this group like humans and remember they are the ones making the money for the company.
cons:
Very difficult to join as an outsider. Veterans have their succession plan decided, and will harm anyone's chances if you stand in the way. Evil tactics used to rid the company of someone they don't like.
Advice to Management
Open up your minds and be willing to listen to new employees who might have good ideas. Don't attempt to replace the person who left with a clone. Everyone has their own personality and ideas, and squelching that is harmful to your company's future.

review_title: SUPERVALU HAS THE FLAVOR OF THE DAY - KEEPS CHANGING STRATEGY
pros: Hard to think of anything positive to say. The people that made the company great are gone and the company lacks direction.
cons:
I worked at one of the retail banners until the company decided to lay off all of the regional staff. The retail banner I once worked for has lost customers, and share of market due to lack of leadership, focus, poor store conditions and lack of community relations. There is poor morale of employees. Management really does not care.
Advice to Management
Listen to your customers, employees and community. It will be hard to regain what you once had. The competition is taking your customers. I worked for the company for many decades but I find it hard to shop in any SUPERVALU store anymore.

review_title: Someday, SVU might be a great place to work
pros: The people actually doing the work are goo, hard-working people who want SVU to be successful.
cons:
The company has been in a pretty constant state of change since 2006. There have been multiple changes in leadership and in strategy.
Helpfu

pros: As has been stated on this site, many people at SuperValu are good, hardworking people. They tend to be the front-line employees.
cons:
A lot of the managers play office politics. Some of them do not have the computer know-how for their jobs. I knew one who barely knew Excel. Also, my current manager likes to delegate the stuff he should be doing to me despite what policy states, and despite the fact that I don't have a lot of time to do his job in addition to my own.

It is hard to fire bad employees. You have to be written up three times to be fired, so a lot of people are in jobs that require detail orientation and are not detail-oriented. Then the rest of us have to fix their mistakes until they either quit or get written up.

There are frequently unrealistic deadlines and not enough people do to the work. Sometimes managers go against the remote policy and forbid people from working at home, even if we could be more effective working from home.

I would not at all be surprised if this company gets bought out in the next few years.
Advice to Management
Dump your dead weight and do more to attract actual talent.
Helpful (3
advice_to_mgmt: Dump your dead weight and do more to attract actual talent.
